We, as gamers have grown, but you know what, so have games! And they seem to be evolving on many fronts and in many different directions. Playdead the studio behind the Xbox 360 title LIMBO, has given us an example of how far games can go as an art form. No, this is not 'just another platformer'. Anyone who dives into LIMBO's arty, black-and-white world, will surely find a good reason to stay. The gameplay itself might be a tad reminiscent of other puzzle-flavored platform classics such as Another World, and even recent titles such as Super Meat Boy and Trine. Heart of Darkness also comes to mind. Even so, LIMBO has a feel of its own.  The central character, a small pale-eyed kid, awakens alone in a murky forest, surrounded by massive trees and a few wondering animals (maggots, tiny butterflies and so on).This is what marks the player's first step into the sinister world of LIMBO. No fancy story, no complex sci-fi universe, no pompous character outlines, no feeble voice-overs... just the tranquil sounds of the deep, black forest. However, as soon as our tiny hero sets out, those tranquil sounds soon transform into a range of rather unsettling noises. Stepping into LIMBO is rather like entering a bleak world of shadows, with but a few flickering light sources that barely manage to outline the silhouettes of nearby objects and creatures.  The creepy forest is no place for a little boy, so it's best to help him get out of danger as soon as possible. LIMBO's perilous dim environment will have you facing dangers around every corner and almost every step could lead our petite hero into a perfectly laid trap. If he isn't cut by exceedingly sharp bear traps or sliced to bits by spinning razor blades, he'll mostly likely run into a blood-thirsty creature. The game throws the player into a series of tough situations where the main character has to fight for his life against overwhelming odds. The game often requires you to get out of these situations by thinking and reacting swiftly, otherwise the cute little boy may get chopped to bits or eaten by something unpleasant.  What's unique about this game is the way it progressively throws different problems your way, without warning and yet somehow always leaves enough time and space for you to solve things on your own. Each step forward tosses you into bigger dangers and tougher physics-based puzzles, in turn may lead to even greater challenges. That's right, physics play an important role as you attempt get out of a range of difficult situations. The puzzles rarely feel repetitive, which was a Godsend. There was an obvious effort by the developers to constantly present something new and unexpected for the player. As a result, the game becomes a joy to play.  It's even more fun to watch and listen, because of its stylish graphics and equally effective audio backdrop. Again, this game doesn't feature fancy graphics, epic soundtracks or a massive cast of top-rated voice actors. Every time a melody starts swelling in the background, that usually means you're in trouble. The ambient music is a perfect match for the game's distinctive art style.  This independently developed title deserves a spot among its many triple-A counterparts, largely because it succeeds in grabbing the attention of both hardcore gamers, as much as those who prefer casual gaming. This highly appealing indie game craves more content though. Well, just more levels, really. Nothing more. It ends to damn quickly. And that's about the only thing I could find wrong with it.   LIMBO may seem like a small ripple in a giant ocean of games, but from where I'm standing, this tiny ripple could easily steer us towards new heights, as games continue to evolve as an art form. It immerses players almost effortlessly thanks to its sleek design and delightfully subtle lighting effects and creepy-looking shadows. LIMBO represents a skillful blend of puzzle-based gameplay mechanics and unique visuals. There isn't an aspect of this game that feels redundant or flimsy. Even though the game left me hungry for more challenges and an altogether lengthier experience, I still see this one as a classic that shouldn't be missed out on.

By now you've probably heard about the highly renowned platformer Limbo. The game has won a bucket full of awards since its release, and rightfully so. Artistically, it was one of the pioneers of the black and white, minimalistic silhouette design; it went on to inspire a plethora of copycats. Though often duplicated, the experience that comes from playing Limbo is one that's unique, and it could never be duplicated even if one tried hard. Originally launching in 2010 for most platforms, the title found its way on to steam in the middle of 2011.   There's no real outward story to speak of, but rather a series of events that the developer, Playdead, have left gamers to interpret for themselves. A small boy wakes up in a new, unforgiving, and sometimes treacherous land, but it soon becomes apparent that he's chasing after someone. The landscape begins as a forest, laden in thick fog, but later turns into a crumbling city. You may think that at some point you'll come across even the tiniest spark of color, but alas all is gloom here. Be prepared to meet some characters that are like you, stuck in the void as they bombard you with obstacles, but most that you meet will be dead; ususally by apparent suicide.  The world of Limbo is filled with platforming puzzles and hazardous traps that will undoubtedly keep you on your toes. While taking in the haunting scenery, you may find yourself victim to stepping on a well hidden bear trap, or not quite making a precision jump that ends with you landing on a bed of spikes. Maybe you think you need to push a box further into the water, only to find out that you cannot swim, and subsequently you drown. Death will come many times over for you, though favorably the checkpoints in this sinister land are forgiving. Much like its aesthetic design, the controls are also simple; you can jump, walk, climb, and move some items.  Truly a haunting, gloomy, and at times depressive experience, Limbo is an amazing platformer. Even those like myself that may not be enthusiasts on the genre will find themselves enjoying this bleak adventure. There's no tutorial, given the simple design of the game. There's no text, the world and its events are left up to your perception and imagination. Despite the lack of narrated story, the game stands strong and immersive. It's one title that you won't forget for years to come. Highly recommended for platformer lovers, enjoyers of the bleak and depressive, and those seeking an unforgettable event. Limbo is a platformer developed by Playdead and their first game, it released in 2010. I played it back when it released, but I decided to give it another chance due to the release of their new game Inside. You play as a young boy, who has gone quite literally through the depths of hell to find his sister. You do this through solving puzzles, killing a few insects, and having more guts than most grown men. Limbo is a spectacular game. The game is a very basic platformer, with only a jump, activate, and move button. The keyboard controls, like for most platformers, just don’t work well with the kind of movement you do in this game. So I would highly advise playing this game with a controller, unless you hate yourself. As far as enemies go, they are really few and far between. You will encounter a few insects that you later interact with in the game. And you will also see other kids that are malicious towards you. I really enjoy the gameplay for most of the time. Only issue I have with it is that some of the puzzles are a bit too complicated, and require you to backtrack and find objects. This may sound normal for a platformer of it’s type, but some of the parts are extremely spread out. I know it sounds nitpicky, and it really is. Throughout the game you are just looking for your sister, so there is not much of a story. But when you come across the many open and industrial places, you can definitely infer that something is seriously screwed up about Limbo. I would also say this game is easily one of the most depressing games I have ever played, nothing good ever happens to the boy. And as I stated earlier, he really does go through hell to accomplish his goal. But I can’t really go into further details about this game’s story without spoiling many of the game’s great moments. The game graphically, while very simple, is quite simply amazing. It has incredible shaders and so much dark but intriguing imagery. It really is one of the prettiest games from an aesthetic standpoint, even if a lot of it is just darkness. The sound in this game is also fantastic. From the ambient sounds in the open moments to the noisy bits in the factory. It really is all around solid stuff, and reminds me a bit of Aphex Twin’s early works. I tried hard to find stuff I had issues with in the game. But there was really so little wrong with the game, it’s a true work of art. I would definitely recommend this game.

When coming to review Limbo, I was surprised to see that my full completion time of the game was only 5.1 hours. I say this, because the game is so incredibly absorbing that it feels like I've spent a wonderful age in that little black and white world.  The game has you play as a lost little guy, trying to save the day, while pretty much everything is trying to kill you.  The style of the game is what sets it apart against other indie games, the wonderful noire-esque artisty which is so easily parodied. It's awesome. The puzzles are of an appropriate level too. I've heard complaints that some were too hard, which forced people to give up. I agree, some were a bit tricky, and I had to close the game for a few hours to work it out, but I don't see that as a problem. If a game can confuse you that much, and make you reflect on it, that is a success.  Everything about the game is brilliant. Highly recommended.  -Nilesy

Really good atmosphere and general artstyle could make this game rise above the others. Unfortunately, I feel that when compared to other puzzle \ platformer games, visuals and sounds are really the only thing that Limbo does well.  There are a few puzzles that are very smart and challenging, but most of the times you'll find the solution right away and you'll have to push some block or run very slowly to the solution. It's boring and irritating to have to spend so much time to solve a puzzle that you could have solved right away... and it's even more irritating to die while solving it, because you jumped a tenth of a second too early ( timing is really the essential skill in here) Other times I felt deaths were a little cheap, with objects that are virtually unavoidable on your first try, since you can't \ won't really see them hanging out in the darkness.  Also, the story. This is very much a personal opinion (as the rest of the review, btw) and I know plenty of people like open ended stories or having to fill in the spots. Still, this is way too much if you ask me. There are so many websites arguing about what this game means, and that's because nothing is explained at all. You wake up in a forest, run away from a spider, then other things, at some point from other humans, then machines, then you find a girl. And I know lots of hints can be gathered by visual imagery, yet these are the only elements that one can know for sure about the plot.  Overall, this game is very short, unexplained and with a gameplay that can be both frustrating and boring. Yes, there are things to be loved here, but I'd suggest thinking twice before buying it (basically if you want something short, visually appealing and interesting, this might actually be for you)

I've always heard of good things about Limbo, but it never piqued my interest enough to buy it until I got it from the HB Store. It's an atmospheric platformer with a minimalist approach to just about everything. When you start the game, you're just shown a little boy in the middle forest, and from there you take over. The main character can only move around, jump, and do certain actions if they're near certain objects such as pull a lever or press a button. There isn't much of a story and it's mostly left up to interpretation but I'm sure that was done on purpose.   If there's one thing that I can truly appreciate about this game it's overall look of the game and the atmosphere it's able to give off. The devs did such a great job making you feel alone as you travel throughtout the game. They did a good job making me feel anxious and even scared as I went through some levels. HOWEVER this is game is far from a masterpiece, it isn't perfect. I was enjoying the game very much until the later half of the game when it changed its approach on level design. They start introducing new gimmicks such as gravity which really put a damper on the game for me personally. It wasn't difficult, but it didn't mesh well with what the game did so well in the first half.  I got my enjoyment out of one playthrough which lasted me about 3.5 hours. I don't feel the need to go back for another playthrough unless I want to get the achievements or eventually forget how the scripted events go. I would recommend getting this on sale unless you are 100% positive that you will do multiple playthroughs for this game since the game is a bit on the short side for 10 dollars.

Limbo is a physics based puzzle platformer, but a first glance at it casts a message as a game full of grim and creepy images. This isn’t a horror game at all as this game is focused on platforming and solving physics puzzles, but Limbo has a distinctly dark atmosphere that suits the style and theme when playing through.  There isn’t too much in terms of story. A boy wakes up in a forest, and as the game description states, tries to find his sister. There is no dialogue at all in the game, as the only things that expand on this story are the various interactions with other people and creatures as you keep moving forward in each level. The story does get resolved later on, though that is something that will be revealed along the way as the game continues.  As a platformer game, the boy that you control doesn’t have much in terms of abilities. All the boy can do is walk, jump, and perform actions on other objects. As the game progresses, new level objects come in to play with different game mechanics to utilize. In the beginning, most puzzles tend to be simple platforming challenges. Later on, more difficult physics puzzles start to appear, requiring some puzzle solving compared to the easy solutions in the beginning. Toward the end, the puzzles are much harder and more involved, also requiring some good timing as well. Throughout the game, trial and error is a core aspect of solving the puzzles. You can definitely get away by being observant and thinking about each puzzle logically, but the harder puzzles require jumping into hazards to see what things do or to get a clue on how to solve the puzzle. The difficulty starts out quite easy, and becomes quite tough near the end of the game that the puzzles require some thought and coordination. Limbo’s simple platforming gameplay gives way for the interesting and well crafted physics puzzles, which require some deaths to successfully complete each puzzle.  The art style for Limbo is one of the biggest motivators for the general tone of the game. The entire game is done like a black and white movie, complete with some film grain and blur to enhance the effect. The 2D design of the world though is quite beautiful in a way, with black silhouettes against gray shaded backgrounds. There is plenty of detail with the background scenery having softer blurred designs while the game objects sport hard, yet rounded shapes. This black and white style does heighten the creepy nature of the game a bit, evoking a feeling like watching old horror movies. The grim, grisly nature of Limbo is evident throughout the game, with many things hiding until they pop out to kill the boy. Early deaths are quite gory and violent, with the boy being dismembered or mauled in several ways. These things work well with the black and white style by simplifying details while still capturing the harshness of the world. These bloody deaths actually happen less later in the game, as more focus shifts on to the puzzles set in a more isolated man made environment. Overall, the dark style of the game works well with the art style for a creepy and bleak world.  Keeping in tune with the dark themes of the game, there are no distinct songs in Limbo. Instead, the game uses an ambient soundtrack that heightens the mood and conveys game information. The sounds of each environment sets the backdrop and the tone, while subtle changes in the music sends a message of what is happening in the game. In addition to the ambient soundtrack adding so much in terms of tone and gameplay, the sound design is very well done. The sounds for the hazards sound distinct from the music which helps players recognize obstacles, while the sounds for deaths sound quite gruesome. With the ambient music and well designed sounds, the eerie atmosphere of the game is heighted more as each action unfolds.  With heavy dark and grim tones, Limbo delivers some fun and somewhat challenging puzzle platforming wrapped up with a unique style. Each of the various aspects of the game work together to deliver this kind of foreboding atmosphere. As the game’s style is draws you in, the gameplay smoothly runs through the world with difficulty arising later on. Limbo works as a great experience of a game, both in the style it achieves, and the puzzle platforming gameplay that offers some good challenge with its crafty levels.

REVIEW:  LIMBO     Limbo  is one of those games I had heard of, but never really put on the to-do list. It was only thanks to the generosity of a friend on Steam that I gained a copy to try and complete. But I haven’t been a fan of platformer games for some time, so would I enjoy  Limbo ?  In a mysterious, monochrome world, a boy awakens in a dark forest. He sets out in search of his sister. But in his way are the various denizens of this world, from giant spiders to parasitic worms, and even other kids…  There are four words that sum up  Limbo : dark, artistic, minimalistic, and frustrating. Easily, the best part of the game is the presentation. It’s dark and moody, the graphics are just right for the macabre style, and the whole atmosphere is enhanced by a dark and appropriate soundtrack. Music and sound effects contribute to an eerie and intimidating atmosphere. It’s like  Silent Hill , but, if anything, even darker. While at first glance it appears to be a kid’s game, it is anything but. I dunno what the rating is, but parents, THIS IS NOT FOR KIDS. This is a violent and dark game. Bleakly beautiful and beautifully bleak, but definitely not for kids.  The gameplay is another matter entirely. It is hard, even by the gold standard of Nintendo platformers. The gameplay consists of avoiding death and figuring out how to progress by trial and error, or as the publishers once called it, ‘trial and death’. And you  will  die. A lot. In manifold gruesome fashions. But figuring out how to get by the latest obstacles or adversaries will give you a feeling of accomplishment. Unfortunately, I tended to get more frustrated than feeling like I accomplished anything meaningful.  The game comes across as the illegitimate offspring of  Silent Hill  and  Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysey  (which, incidentally, was recently re-released on Steam). While the difficulty feels right for such a game, I just wish it wasn’t quite so hard. And the payoff in the minimalist story doesn’t quite work.  That being said,  Limbo  is pretty good. I like it mainly for the presentation more than the gameplay, but the gameplay itself has its own charms. It’s just a touch too hard for my liking…   RATING: ***½

Limbo is a beautiful, atmospheric puzzle platformer with a hard edge. What story it has is largely implicit—the game contains no dialogue. You simply wake in a dark wood, apparently a child, and set off to explore the dingy place in which you find yourself. But the genre of the game is certainly horror, though without most of the usual tropes. You are fragile—easily hurt, unable to swim, essentially defenseless—in a hostile and trap-ridden place. You will die many times. And the game does not divert your gaze from your death but rather renders each different mode of your demise in somewhat disturbing detail.   The artistic style of the game simultaneously keeps this from being too macabre and contributes greatly to the eerie atmosphere. The game's graphics are entirely silhouettes in shades of grey. Yet the landscapes and objects feel very detailed. Beautifully done lighting effects give the impression of a layered world mostly in shadow. All this makes for a beautiful noir environment well worth admiration in its own right. This game is more immersive with black and white outlines than much I’ve played that had expensive 3D-graphics.  A subtler strength of the game is the way its physics feel naturalistic—you are acutely aware of the weight of objects and the force of gravity. I doubt that the game’s engine is particularly remarkable in this regard, it’s an aesthetic effect. Great attention has been paid to the visual details of motion. But I think it also comes from player movement: in many games you play as a character with outsized physical capabilities. Even in shooters and platformers where such isn’t part of the story your movements are subtly superhuman (think of the lateral jumping featured in most platformers). Not here. Here you have a painfully tiny lateral jump and a rather slow top speed. Here objects don’t just slide easily into place but are dragged only with great effort.  The largest complaint I had with LIMBO was that it was too short. Though the puzzles were good, and admirably varied, not too many were very difficult. If one is adept at this sort of thing one could easily complete the game in just a few hours. They are an excellent few hours though. The puzzles are crisp, things to be grasped, not just fiddled with. For a little while LIMBO takes you to an unsettling, engrossing otherworld. And I’d very much like to visit again.

I had this game on my wishlist for awhile as it seemed to have been unanimously praised. When it was offered for free on Steam 6/21 and 6/22, I was eager to try it out. I was ultimately very disappointed with the game. Several times during my playthrough, I commented to friends that had I purchased  Limbo , I likely would have refunded the game without hesitation.   Positives:    + The graphic style is unique and the developers succeeded in creating an atmosphere that makes the player feel isolated and uncertain. It reminded me a bit of how  Spider-Man: Shattered Dimensions  used the noir graphics. From an aesthetic standpoint,  Limbo  is a treat. The game runs at a constant 60FPS (locked) at 1080p.  + The game length (about 3-4 hours on a first playthrough) is just about right. I didn't really want to play it any more than this (more on this below).  + The checkpoint system is generous. Given the instant-death, trial-and-error nature of the puzzles, it is necessary.   Negatives:    - The trial-and-error nature of the puzzles is more frustrating than it is motivating. Successfully overcoming the objectives doesn't feel rewarding and oftentimes the solutions can only be discovered by dying repeatedly. Cheap deaths occur regularly, often from unavoidable hazards intentionally obscured by the shadows.  Limbo  seems to go for the 'gotcha' and it ranges from irritating to frustrating. There is one particular puzzle (about 2/3rds through) where the game provides a paradigm to follow and then a second later rips the carpet out from under the player by shifting it so that the same action results in instant death. It isn't clever. I enjoy games that challenge me to think, and failing in games like  Portal  or  The Talos Principle  felt fair and motivated me to try again.  Limbo  left me wanting to press on simply so I could get through the game. After 3-4 hours, I had enough.  - Movement feels floaty. The best comparison I could make would be  Little Big Planet  as that also features wonky platorming, but  Limbo  is worse. For a game that oftentimes requires precise timing/jumping, character movement is oftentimes sluggish.  - The game lacks any graphics options and in general the settings are extremely bare-bones. Before playing through  Limbo  I thought this was at worst an oversight, at best an attempt by the developer to emphasize the experience rather than having the user worry about tweaking framerates and texture levels. After playing, I am inclined to think this was a conscious decision done not in the spirit of emphasizing a certain aesthetic but rather to scold the player for daring to want to adjust or customize the experience to their liking. Maybe that's unfair, but given the 'gotcha' moments experienced in the puzzles, it combined with the lack of options to give me that sort of feeling.   Conclusion:   Had I paid for this game, I would have refunded it. Given that it was offered free for a limited time, all I lost was my time.  Limbo  is a game that has a unique aesthetic that is tarnished by the worst sort of trial-and-error puzzles, I would  not  recommend this game.

LIMBO is everything an indie game should be. Today, games are often made simply because they will sell. Games with huge budgets, top-notch graphics, and the most advanced AI can make millions of dollars and yet only provide the player with a lifeless experience. LIMBO puts you in a world that is devoid of color, music, and narrative and yet proves to be entertaining, challenging, and able to invoke emotion in the player.   LIMBO is a puzzle-platformer with very simple controls. It doesn't give you a tutorial or hold your hand. It drops you in a lonely and hostile environment and let's you figure out for yourself how to advance and how to survive. The controls are tight and the puzzles are creative and challenging without being too frustrating. You'll never be scratcing your head for too long and finding the solution to a puzzle is always satisfying. Some may complain about the trial and error process of dying and retrying. I felt that this helped to enrich the dark atmosphere with a genuine sense of peril which is very important to the game. From beginning to end, the player feels a sense of helplessness. Even though our protagnist is silent, we can sense that he is lost and confused by his hostile surroundings. This makes the need to solve puzzles all the more necessary to the player as these small victories are what drive the player to move forward and discover the secrets of this strange and beautiful black-and-white world.   10/10

LIMBO is a standard side-scroller with some physics here-and-there, nothing too impressive. The story isn't well fleshed out, almost nonexistent, although the developers claim it's up to the gamer to interpret it. But considering how inconsistent the second half of the game felt compared to the first, I attribute it to laziness or lack of direction. However, LIMBO has some redeeming qualities--it's art style and music. The developers took a minimalist approach and chose only to us white, black, and gray. The environments are diverse and look beautiful to say the least. And the music, when it pops up, really grabs your attention and sets the mood. It was something I enjoyed listening to, so much so in fact that I bought the soundtrack.

I really, really wanted to enjoy LIMBO, but the more I played it, the more irritated I got. It's got that typical and extremely pervasive problem with puzzle-platformers of being overly reliant on timing-based puzzles rather than thought-based ones, meaning that the tiniest mistake can and will end up killing you in some gruesome way despite the solution being painfully obvious. Add to that the basically nonexistent story and storytelling, and it fails miserably as a game. But I get the feeling it's not meant to be seen as a game, but rather a piece of art, which it succeeds at brilliantly. The grim, oppressive atmosphere ingame is absolutely phenomenal and the artistic nature of it wanting you to come to your own conclusions is a massively refreshing change of pace. I'd say check out the demo, and if you like that then you'll like the rest of the game.

Another favourite indie game, LIMBO has easy gameplay but there are also tricky and unfair action-puzzle moments and lots of dying. You'll also use the bodies of others to help you move forward, though this doesn't happen much. The tricky action-puzzle moments are, for example, like timing and pressing two floor buttons to drop two crates and maneuvering one so that the other lands on it, then climbing them in order to jump over an approaching rotating saw. There are going to be so many deaths from the trial-and-error puzzles. But there are plenty of checkpoints so it doesn't feel like wasted effort. Still, what were they thinking by putting in an unrealistic achievement for completing the game in one sitting in 5 or less lives? I know this game pretty well and finished it in under 2.5 hours but died many times over some truly unfair challenges -- like trying to do a perfect jump arc over a moving, rotating saw, in pitch blackness. First-timers will be killed by traps that they either don't see or they don't recognize. And this game deliberately confuses you with an art design that doesn't distinguish foreground from background and interactive objects from set dressing. So, you see, you can enjoy this game with the understanding that failure is okay and that you'll eventually make it through to completion. Doing a perfect run is for the few.  The atmosphere and sound design resembles the work of David Lynch and Alan Splet from the movie Eraserhead.

I wasn't sure if I should've recommended this game or warned people away. Personally, I hated the game.  Let's be clear here, I was very conflicted while playing this. In the first few sections, it was creepy and intruiging. The art style, while a bit dull and at times inhibitive to the gameplay, is rarely seen in visual media. The deaths were shocking and gruesome, and game paid little attention to them. My favorite moment was the giant spider chase; I never thought I'd be so terrified in a platformer. It's creative and morbid, two game concepts that often work well together. Once I got to the factory, however, it seemed like everything changed.   Gone were the organic horrors and the inviting atmosphere. The absence of a soundtrack was refreshing at first, yet quickly became boring in that there wasn't another source of tension. There was of course the constant threat of death, yet it was almost encouraged in order to solve the puzzles. The only source of anxiety came from the puzzles themselves, which felt more like a spot-the-difference than a mental excercise. I found myself constantly checking walkthroughs, simply because I couldn't discern which objects I could interact with. This made for an increasingly infuriating experience. And since the puzzles were the only source of stress, every section that wasn't a puzzle was just boring. There were very few chapters in which I felt a sense of achievement after completing them.   The ending is it's own seperate conclusion. [SPOILERS AHEAD]  I've read many reviews that say the game's story is deep and meaningful. And that may be true, but it won't feel like that when you finish it. If I hadn't read the single-line description before playing it, I would've guessed that it was a cut-and-paste love story, where a boy goes through the death-ridden landscape of Limbo to get the girl (it's actually his sister :/ ). Except... she doesn't look to be in any danger. In fact, she looks almost oblivious to the hellish obstacle course right next to her. So what does that mean for you? Were your efforts for nothing? Were those trials even real? Was it a metaphor for the mental obstacles in your own mind? The traditional happy ending raises more questions than answers.  [SPOLIERS END]  Throughout my whole playthrough, I was consantly reminded of Cormac McCarthy's 'The Road'. It has the same sense of silence, the same dreary atmosphere; the monochrome landscape would feel right at home. 'The Road' also has deep themes and meaning, although its a little easier to infer and understand since its primarily in first person. With Limbo, we don't have that same sense of immersion or insight. The ending is the only real bit of story, and it doesn't really explain anything. I tried to find a theme that wasn't along the lines of 'effort is meaningless' or 'death is to be accepted', but couldn't find anything outside of an emo's diary. I fully admit that the fault may be mine, and that most people might be able to see what I can't. It's the nature of artistic indie games.  Bottom line: would I recommend it? I left it feeling wholly unsatisfied. It was maddening to play, and the ending was severely underwhelming.   As a game? Hell no, at least not at full price. The game only lasts about 2 hours and there's very little replayability. I got it for $2.50, so wait for a sale and you might find it more fulfilling than I did.   As an artistic venture however, go for it. It's very difficult to take a piece of art and merge it with entertaining gameplay. It doesn't deter from the experience much, but it might not be what you expect a game to be (if you've ever played a TellTale game you'll see what I'm trying to get at).   All in all, it's not worth $10, but its not worthless either.    [please do not comment what you think the meaning is. if it's there, i want to discern it for myself. thank you.]

LIMBO is a linear puzzle-solving platformer where you face simple to complex challenges as you venture through a noir, somewhat-sadistic world. The gameplay itself is simplified to simply movement and a single action key.  There is no background music, but this game is not meant to have any. The atmosphere within the game is intended to invoke feelings of solitude and helplessness.  Personally I'm sure there's a lot going on in this game, but I'm not really good when it comes to thinking about these sorts of things, so I'll take everyone's word for it that there's a lot to think about.  For the gameplay itself, I am pleased with it. The puzzles can be difficult or tedious at times, but you do get a feeling of satisfaction whenever you complete them.

Compared to 'Braid,' 'Limbo' leaves me unsure of what to say about it.  Set aside a few hours and try to play through it in one sitting. It is both a beautiful and very sad game. Little in the game tells you what it's about in a conventional manner, but as you play, you'll figure it out for yourself, through all of the soul-crushing solitude.  I think that's a good description of 'Limbo.' It's a very personal game. And at the end, through all of the darkness and loneliness, beauty shatters it all.

Story: There doesn't seem to be any. You're a boy stuck in some kind of horror world. Some people want to kill you but you're not really sure why. I suppose you're trying to escape the place but i am not sure why you're there anyway. I guess you're trying to get to your girlfriend? Really lacking here. Critically praised, LIMBO had me eagerly awaiting Steam's next big sale to finally get my hands on it. The time finally came and as I enthusiastically booted up the game, I found myself coming out of it a mere two hours later, unsatisfied and cheated.  LIMBO shares a lot of similarity with another puzzle platformer, Braid. They're both of the same genre and boast an extremely unique art style. For all its mental stimulation and beautiful aesthetics, LIMBO is indeed a 'masterpiece' in its own right.  My assumption is that the developers approached this game with a minimalistic mindset. The player is only given five actions keys: to move and to use. The only colors are black and white and their different shades and the only sounds are ambient noises. Soundtrack, dialogue, and text are nonexistent.  While clever and engaging throughout, the game is ridiculously short and offers little to no replay value. It's a 'gem' that's easy on the eyes, but one not worthy of its price tag.  Grade: C

LIMBO places the player in a dark world where a mysterious story unfolds as they complete puzzle after puzzle. I must say that the story is very moving at first; it's dreadful and heartbreakingly sinister. But after the first-bit of the terrifying giant spider part, I quickly fell into boredom. It's as if the climax is already over and the rest of the gameplay is the falling action. I spent most of my time pressing levers and buttons of machinery equipments without the pressure and excitement of something chasing me down, like the feeling I got after I first encountered the spider. I would prefer the second half of the gameplay match the tension and excitement of the first. The background music (mostly silence) fits the atmosphere of the game well. The minimalistic but beautiful art design sets the mood. Overall, this is a nicely polished game that all puzzle lovers should experience.

LIMBO is a puzzle/platformer equivalent to an Edgar Allen Poe poem. TL;DR :: Very superb artwork, horrific deaths, good use of simple methods to create intense moments of action, weird story line that started out very well but was steadily lost on me until the end when it finally died altogether.   Pros: Artwork, audio, puzzles and mechanics, free! (at least it was for me)  Cons: Controls and artwork sometimes adds to the difficulty, wrecking the immersion. Lack of options (couldn't go 21:9 and can't change controls).  This game started out very well. You are told nothing, and wake up as a boy in some 2d dark forest land. Nothing left to do but go onward. Incredible artwork and audio that fully compliments the narrative kept me interested nearly the whole way though. The surprising game mechanics that were mixed up with creative puzzles to solve felt mostly rewarding.   However...  For a game that relies so much on control and timing dexterity I found myself more than once cursing at the controls. The lack of ability to change those controls (on PC at least) was further irritating, as was not being able to take advantage of my ultra wide monitor (no biggy though). The artwork, which started out as a real gem slowly began to irritate me as I progressed through the game. It can be difficult to know what is a black wall that you cannot pass, and what is simply a dark black shadow representing an art asset that you can walk through, or even interact with.   I thought this game would be story focused due to it's rad beginning, but it sort of rapidly changed to increasingly difficult puzzles to solve with confusing story elements to which there is no resolution due to it's incredly lack luster ending.   Overall, I didn't pay for the game, so it's incredible as a freebie. But if I had spent $10 or less on it I would highly recommend it, and so I do. I hear there is another title (INSIDE) just released from the same Studio and I do intend to pick it up. If it's just as good as Limbo (or better, which I think it will be) hopefully it will offer some follow up to the bismal ending of this game. It's also worth mentioning that it's a pretty short game.

With a bit of retro atmosphere, black-and-white pleasant backgrounds and, I don't know, a playful kid lovingly prancing around in a fond search for his sister? Yeah, well, no. Limbo is macabre, is dark, is scary and truly isn't the right game for someone as jumpy and nervy as me. I had to stop a few times to calm down and I closed my eyes during at least half of the deaths. Of COURSE it's black and white, you really don't want to see SO MUCH RED on your screen.  You won't be able to play this game if you're arachnophobic; you won't be able to play this game if you're scared by deep waters and, likely, if you often suffer from vertigo. I think you'll better be careful if you're against gore and if seeing a child - yeah, I know it's a smallish cartoonish cutout, still a child - being hurt is going to unsettle you. By the way, the last warning goes for me, too.  Even so, this game is one of the things nearest to perfection I've ever played with. The graphic! Graphics are wonderful, from the wonderful font choosen for the title, from the menu and the first background up to each one of those black silhouettes of monsters and enemies and traps, each one perfectly in tone and easy recognizable despite the surrounding misty darkness. The soundtrack, soft and barely there, carrying you on through the scariest moments and keeping you on your toes! Each one of those marvellous, problematic, complex, truly original puzzles: you won't be able to get bored, there're no dead times, there's no pause, no slowing down up to the very end.  I've a lot of PROs and just a few CONs, so, let's go on.  PROs: - Detailed, interesting, original graphics. Wonderful. No colours at all to distract you from beautiful lines and marvellously designed backgrounds. - Themed atmosphere. All the atmosphere you'll ever want in a game and more. You really need to play Limbo in a dark room, I've jumped so many times I think I've drilled an hole in the chair. - Useful and pleasant sounds/soundtrack. There isn't a clear music going on, more a kind of soft, vibrating sound sometimes taking consistency and sometimes leaving everything in the deepest silence. Sounds are a completing and essential part of the whole experience and you'll need them to solve more easily a few puzzles. - Complex obstacles. Like I said, each one of them is original and interesting; they're disposed by growing difficulty and different sceneries will have different themes going on. Loved it. - Well-built animations. They're sometimes lovely and more often unsettling and always wonderfully rendered. You can interact with lots of things in your playground and your character will react to each one of them in a different way. Truly not a sloppy work. Really, it's the care poured in each detail which made me fall in love.  CONs: - Total lack of explanations. Like, I've got it, really, you want me to explore and discover, but I'm not asking for much - thirty seconds of an introductive sequence to try and get me understanding your choice of controls? I come from a time when double clicking the Up Arrow got you jumping higher and clicking it for a longer time got you... nothing. If it's a deliberate way to skim out less expert and/or older players, I can understand it, but low blow, guys, low blow.  - No warnings. Like, at all. And I think that's a game which would need them deeply. I usually buy new games without reading any review, to preserve the full surprise effect, and this time the tagline was a bit misleading. Please, warn me about the HUGE SPIDERS - I like spiders, but I don't like them when they're trying to skewering me - and the fact that I'll be DISEMBOWELED at least a few times during the game, and all of this while I'm a child. - No introduction. You know that you're searching for your sister because you've read the tagline. And what if you got this game as a gift? Or if you're playing it at a friends' place? I think a game has to start with the first scene and end with the last one; here, if you haven't read the tagline, you won't be able to truly understand the last scene. Which is, by the way, ambiguous and wonderful.  This is the kind of game you play and play and play again trying to beat your own best time - and your own death count. I'm surely restarting it right now.   9/10.

I picked this up for free when the dev put on a special 24 hour event as part of the release of their new game.  First off, the name LIMBO is absolutely stupid for this game. I have never theologically seen Limbo represented as a place of such ghastly mechanical doom, which seems like attempted and failed artsiness.  Secondly, part of me wanted to hate this game from the beginning, because games that attempt to be art typically fail at both. I've played Ico, Shadow of the Collosus, Heavy Rain, and other 'art games' and generally feel that most fail spectacularly at being both games and art.  This game commits sins by offering puzzles that are so pedantic at some points that you will want to find a way to punch the developers in the face. At the same time, when you best a puzzle or survive one on the first try, the high you get is absolutely worth it.  So yes, it's a pretentious, pretentious game. It's only mildly entertaining. But it is a begrudging recommendation from me nonetheless as a fair way to spend half a day.
